Rose, I’m happy with the progress you’ve made - genuinely. You’ve made great strides! There is always room for improvement for all of us, but I genuinely think you’ve made great progress! The only other possible suggestion I would have, without being there in person or communicating through video chat, would be to practice the scripts as a one on one conversation with someone. It can help familiarize yourself with the material and further refine the natural ebb and flow of conversations. I do want to place emphasis on the practice being like a one sided conversation. This usually helps break people out of the unnatural feeling or flow most people have when presenting. Good job! I look forward to seeing you in future videos! Best of luck!

I have an idea, but first: would it be possible to count or get a ratio of viruses and protists in a container? If so, you could try inferring from the evidence of population ratios changing to determine which is eating or infecting the other, so long as the two colonies are in a sterile environment.

From what I recall, viruses can only reproduce by infecting others to make the victim do the dirty work for them, but in a roundabout way, the protists can only reproduce when they consume something to add biomass to fuel the production of the next generation. If they're starved of another food source, then one colony will eventually consume the other, so whichever one comes out on top is the predator, right?

I guess it would be like putting a cat in a box with a bunch of rats, then closing it and coming back after some time to see if there are no rats, or if the cat was overwhelmed by the rats and they ate it. Of course, you need to control for thing like providing air and water, and removing feces/urine, and ruling out that the cat died of unrelated causes leading to the rats scavenging, etc, etc, etc, but that's tye general idea. You don't necessarily need to observe the act if you can control for enough variables to give a fairly accurate assumption of the act based on the evidence said act leaves behind, right?

"protists" are an outdated category a lump all bin for eukaryotes that are not macroscopic animals plants or fungi. If you are going to describe where an organism falls on the tree of life protist is useless after all phylogenetically a monophyletic protist category is synonymous with Eukaryote. Please actually tell us what the organism is and don't just use an outdated lump all bin category.

After all we now have a much better understanding of the major Eukaryotic divisions of life even if it is still crude and evolving as new and better information becomes available but it at least would give us a much better picture of what this organism is.
